item.title: Parallel computation of Do loop using Openmpi in Fortran
item.description:
1. Key command

use omp_lib

!$OMP PARALLEL 
!$OMP DO

!$OMP END DO
!$OMP END PARALLEL

or

use omp_lib

!$OMP PARALLEL DO

!$OMP END PARALLEL DO

2. File

The content of the file test.f90 is:

program main

    use omp_lib
    implicit integer (i-n)
    implicit real*8 (a-h,o-z)

    real(8),allocatable:: number(:,:)

    inumber=2
    jnumber=3
    allocate(number(inumber,jnumber))

    write(*,*) "parallel do"

    call cpu_time(time_begin1)
    !$OMP PARALLEL DO
    do i=1,inumber
        do j=1,jnumber
            number(i,j)=i+j
            write(*,*) i,j,number(i,j), OMP_get_thread_num()
        enddo
    enddo
    !$OMP END PARALLEL DO
    call cpu_time(time_end1)
    write(*,*) "The time cost is",time_end1-time_begin1

    do i=1,inumber
        do j=1,jnumber
            write(*,*) i,j,number(i,j)
        enddo
    enddo

    deallocate(number)

end program main

The content of the file job.sh is:

item.title: Fortran relational operators (LT/LE/GT/GE/EQ/NE)
item.description:
1. Relational operators

Code Symbol Meaning
.LT. < Less Than
.LE. <= Less or Equal
.GT. > Greater Than
.GE. >= Greater or Equal
.EQ. = Equal
.NE. /= Not Equal

item.title: Using Fortran in Python: f2py
item.description:
1. Usage

  1. Open the jupyter notebook:
jupyter notebook
  1. The basic information is:
In[1]: import os, sys

In[2]: %config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import scipy.fftpack as sf
import scipy.linalg as sl
import numpy as np
  1. Create the fortran file euclidian_norm.f90:
In[3]: %%file euclidian_norm.f90
subroutine euclidian_norm (a, b, c)
  real(8), intent(in) :: a, b
  real(8), intent(out) :: c 
  c = sqrt (a*a+b*b) 
end subroutine euclidian_norm
  1. Build extension module with f2py program:
In[4]: !{sys.executable} -m numpy.f2py --quiet -c euclidian_norm.f90 -m vect

A vect.so file will be obtained.

  1. Use the extension module in Python:
In[5]: import vect
c = vect.euclidian_norm(3,4)
c
Out[5]: 5.0
  1. The basic information of vect.euclidian_norm is:
In[6]: print(vect.euclidian_norm.__doc__)

c = euclidian_norm(a,b)

Wrapper for ``euclidian_norm``.

Parameters
----------
a : input float
b : input float

Returns
-------
c : float

2. Reference

  • F2py â€” Python-Fortran notebooks

item.title: GNSS-IR tools using Fortran and Matlab
item.description:
1. Introduction

Download: https://geodesy.noaa.gov/gps-toolbox/exist.htm

2. References

Roesler, C., Larson, K.M. Software tools for GNSS interferometric reflectometry (GNSS-IR). GPS Solution, 22, 80 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10291-018-0744-8

item.title: PGPLOT Graphics Subroutine Library
item.description:
Introduction

The PGPLOT Graphics Subroutine Library is a Fortran- or C-callable, device-independent graphics package for making simple scientific graphs.

Main Page: https://sites.astro.caltech.edu/~tjp/pgplot/

Installation Instructions: https://sites.astro.caltech.edu/~tjp/pgplot/install.html

item.title: LitMod3D: 3â€D model of lithosphere
item.description:
1. Introduction

LitMod3D is a software for 3D integrated geophysical-petrological interactive modelling of the lithosphere and underlying upper mantle using a variety of input datasets: potential fields (gravity and magnetic), surface heat flow, elevation (isostasy), seismics, magnetotellurics and geochemical.

Download:

  • https://github.com/eldarbaykiev/litmod
  • https://github.com/javfurchu/litmod
  • https://www.juanafonso.com/software

2. Reference

Fullea, J., Afonso, J. C., Connolly, J. A. D., Fernandez, M., GarcÃ­aâ€Castellanos, D., & Zeyen, H. (2009). LitMod3D: An interactive 3â€D software to model the thermal, compositional, Density, seismological, and rheological structure of the lithosphere and sublithospheric upper mantle. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 10(8). https://doi.org/10.1029/2009GC002391

item.title: FA2BOUG: Fortran code to determine the Bouguer anomaly
item.description:
1. Introduction

FA2BOUG: determine the Bouguer anomaly from publicly available global gridded free-air anomaly and elevation database sets.

Download: Appendix A. Supplementary Materials at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cageo.2008.02.018

2. Reference

Fullea, J., Fernandez, M., & Zeyen, H. (2008). FA2BOUGâ€”A FORTRAN 90 code to compute Bouguer gravity anomalies from gridded free-air anomalies: Application to the Atlantic-Mediterranean transition zone. Computers & Geosciences, 34(12), 1665-1681. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cageo.2008.02.018

item.title: SRBF_package: spherical radial basis functions
item.description:
1. Introduction

SRBF_package is a collection of a few routines for gravity field modelling with band-limited spherical radial basis functions (SRBFs), allowing both analysis and synthesis of the gravitational field.

Website:

  • Bucha/#SRBF_package
  • http://edisk.cvt.stuba.sk/~xbuchab/SRBF_package/SRBF_package.zip

2. Reference

Bucha, B., JanÃ¡k, J., PapÄo, J., BezdÄ›k, A., 2016. High-resolution regional gravity field modelling in a mountainous area from terrestrial gravity data. Geophysical Journal International. 207, 949-966. http://doi.org/10.1093/gji/ggw311

item.title: SHA_SHS: spherical harmonic analysis and synthesis
item.description:
1. Introduction

Download:

  • Bucha/#SHA
  • http://edisk.cvt.stuba.sk/~xbuchab/SHA_code/SHA_SHS.zip

2. Reference

Bucha, B., Hirt, C., Kuhn, M., 2019. Cap integration in spectral gravity forward modelling up to the full gravity tensor. Journal of Geodesy. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00190-019-01277-3

item.title: SHTools & pyshtools: Tools for Working with Spherical Harmonics
item.description:
1. Introduction

SHTOOLS/pyshtools is a Fortran-95/Python library that can be used to perform spherical harmonic transforms, multitaper spectral analyses, expansions of functions into Slepian bases, and standard operations on global gravitational and magnetic field data.

GitHub: https://github.com/SHTOOLS/SHTOOLS

Download: https://github.com/SHTOOLS/SHTOOLS/releases

pyshtools’s documentation: https://shtools.github.io/SHTOOLS/

SHTOOLS documentation: https://shtools.github.io/SHTOOLS/index-fortran.html

2. Reference

Wieczorek, M. A., & Meschede, M. (2018). Shtools: Tools for working with spherical harmonics. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 19(8), 2574-2592. https://doi.org/10.1029/2018GC007529

item.title: pyGravsoft: python GRAVSOFT gravity field programs
item.description:
1. Introduction

pyGravsoft is a Python interface to GRAVSOFT gravity field programs.

GRAVSOFT is a package of FORTRAN programs for gravity field modelling. The specific use of the programs for the determination of the empirical covariance function and its analytic modelling and geoid determination using least-squares collocation is described.

PDF: An overview manual for the GRAVSOFT Geodetic Gravity Field Modelling Programs

2. Reference

Nielsen, J., Tscherning, C. C., Jansson, T. R. N., & Forsberg, R. (2009). Development of a Python interface to the GRAVSOFT gravity field programs. In Proceedings of the 2009 IAG General Assembly, Buenos Aires, August 31- September 4, 2009 (pp. 325-331). Springer Science+Business Media.

	program hello_world
      
      use mpi
      !include 'mpif.h'
      integer ierr, num_procs, my_id

      call MPI_INIT ( ierr )
      ! find out my process ID, and how many processes were started.
      call MPI_COMM_RANK (MPI_COMM_WORLD, my_id, ierr)
      call MPI_COMM_SIZE (MPI_COMM_WORLD, num_procs, ierr)

      print *, "Hello world! I'm process ", my_id, " out of ", num_procs, " processes."

      call MPI_FINALIZE ( ierr )
